characters: BACK TO RAY FROM ACROSS THE DESK

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR NIGHT
dialogues.text: We are looking at the backs of two people in the front se a man, driving, and a woman next to him. Their conversation will be punctuated by the occasional g of oncoming headlights and the roar of the car rushing by The windshield wipers wave a soporific beat. The conversa is halting, awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He gave me a little pearl-handled  .38 for out first anniversary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Figured I'd better leave before I  used it on him. I don't know how you  can stand him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm only an employee, I ain't  married to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause, as an oncoming car passes. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't know. Sometimes I think  there's something wrong with him.  Like maybe he's sick? Mentally?...  Or is it maybe me, do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I ain't a marriage counselor.  I don't know what goes on, I don't  wanna know... But I like you. I always  liked you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another car passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What're you gonna do in Houston?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll figure something out... How  come you offered to drive me in this  mess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you. I like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, I never knew that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another pause. Another car. Suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop the car, Ray!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stamped on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Low three-quarters on the car as it squeals to a halt. A car that has been following screeches to a halt just be it. Both cars sit. Rain patters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on the man, from behind. He looks at the woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Abby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't answer. He turns to look back and we see his  face, for the first time, in the headlights of the car be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car behind them waiting, patiently. Rain drifts down  past its headlights. Finally it pulls out and passes them slowly, their headli showing it to be a battered green Volkswagon. First the c itself, then its red taillights, disappear into the rain.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE MAN
dialogues.text: Cutting between him and the woman, each from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You know that car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... I just think maybe  I'm making a mistake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What was that back there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Motel... Abby--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray. Did you mean that, what you  said before, or were you just being  a gentleman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby, I like you, but it's no point  starting anything now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I ain't a marriage counselor--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man is uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman is uncomfortable. After a long pause:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL ROOM
dialogues.text: Pulling back from RAY and ABBY in bed, making love. The only light is from cars passing along the highway out Each sweeping light-by ends in black. The pullback ends in a wide shot of the motel room. The b following the last car lingers. A telephone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Abby are asleep. On a nightstand next to the bed, the telephone is ringing. Ray stirs, reaches for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having a good time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What? Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, who's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence at both ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You still there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm still here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray listens to another silence. It ends with a disconnect Abby is stirring as Ray gets out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Ray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband.

dialogues.speaker: BAR BACK OFFICE NIGHT
dialogues.text: We are tracking past a man seated behind a wooden desk,  towards an 8 x 10 black-and-white photograph that has jus been slapped down on the desktop. The picture is of Abby and Ray in bed together in the mot room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a place you can get that  framed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice is familiar as that of the narrator whose musin on life in Texas and the Soviet Union opened the movie. We cut to him. He is settling himself into a chair facing the desk. He i LOREN VISSER, a large unshaven man in a misshapen yellow  leisure suit. He smiles at the man behind the desk.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN MARTY
dialogues.text: Sits staring down at the photograph. Behind him a window  opens on the bar proper. Country-western music filters in from the bar. Marty is not pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you take these for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He removes a pouch of tobacco from his breast pocket and  nonchalantly starts rolling a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Just doin' my job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You called me, I knew they were there,  so what do I need these for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know... Call it a fringe  benefit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long did you watch her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lights his cigarette, then slaps his lighter onto the  desktop. It is silver, engraved on the top with a lariat spelling "Loren" in script, and on the side with a declaration tha he is "Elks Man of the Year."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...They'd just rest a few minutes  and then get started again. Quite  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty stares down at the photograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know in Greece they cut off the  head of the messenger who brought  bad news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smoke ring floats into frame from offscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that don't make much sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It just made them feel better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty rises and goes to a safe behind his desk. Visser laughs as he watches Marty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well first off, Julian, I don't know  what the story is in Greece but in  this state we got very definite laws  about that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty, hunched over the standing safe behind his desk, to in the photograph and takes out a pay envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Second place I ain't a messenger,  I'm a private investigator. And third  place--and most important--it ain't  such bad news. I mean you thought he  was a colored. (he laughs) ...You're always assumin' the worst...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visser blows another smoke ring, pushes a fat finger thro the middle of it, and beams at Marty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, don't come by here any more.  If I need you again I know which  rock to turn over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty scales the pay envelope across the desk. It hits Vi in the chest and bounces to the floor. Visser looks stonily down at the envelope; no expression a beat. Then he roars with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good... "which rock to turn  over"... that's very good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sighing, he leans forward to pick up the envelope. He ris straightens his cowboy hat, and walks over to a screen do letting out on the bar's back parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, gimme a call whenever you wanna  cut off my head...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses at the door, cocks his head, then turns back to the desk and picks up his cigarette lighter. Returning to the door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I can crawl around without it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door slams shut behind him. Marty scowls at the back door. After a moment he rises an crosses the office to the window looking out on the bar. Over Marty's shoulder we see the long bar leading up to t window in perpendicular. The camera is tracking forward,  past Marty, to frame on the window. A black man is just now vaulting the near end of the bar, over onto the customer side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracking back with him as he lands on the customer side a heads across the bar. This shot, from the other side of t back-office window, reveals the window to be one-way glas mirrored on this side MEURICE, the black bartender, is muscular, about 200 poun dressed in white pants and a sleeveless T-shirt. He is ma his way through the crowd towards the jukebox. Another man stands in front of it examining the selection He deposits a quarter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it, hold it. What's tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What night is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying Meurice) ...Friday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Friday night is Yankee night.  Where're you from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lubbock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meurice shakes his head and punches the selector buttons the jukebox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. I'm from Detroit (turning to leave) It's a big city up north with tall  buildings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Motown song drops. We track behind Meurice as he makes way back toward the bar. When he reaches it, he claps a c of people on the shoulder, who make way for him. He vault back over the top, walks down the bar, and stops in from an attractive white woman sitting on a bar stool and sipp a brandy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where was I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You we telling me about the Ring of  Fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I may be getting in over  my head here, I mean you're the  geologist, but my theory for what  it's worth, you got all these  volcanoes and each time one pops  it's the equivalent of what, twenty,  thirty megatons of TNT?  Enough to  light Las Vegas for how long?  How  many years? Course, I'm no  mathematician but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty is approaching from the direction of the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. Pour 'em short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has Ray come in yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's off tonight. Where was he  last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glaring) How would I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, didn't he call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty loses his glare and his gaze drifts over to the wom After an awkward pause, Meurice clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Marty, I'd like you to meet an  old friend of mine, Debra. Debra,  this is Julian Marty, the dude I'm  always talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is unselfconsciously returning Marty's stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he does come in I'm not here...  What were you drinking, Debra?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a very sophisticated  palate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give Debra here another drink, and  give me the usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meurice walks down the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What's a palate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty studies her for a beat, she studies him, he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I got tickets for the Oilers  and the Rams next week in the  Astrodome. Ever sat on the fifty  yard line?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't follow baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't have to. I'll explain what  a palate is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't have to. I just wanted to  see if you knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty smiles bleakly. Debra drains her glass as Meurice  returns. He sets another Cognac in front of Debra, and a  glass of milk in front of Marty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said the usual--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red Label.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up the milk) Right. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pour that back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't throw that out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wanders on down the bar; Marty's attention returns to woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how long have you know Meurice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About ten years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty's attention is caught by something down the bar. He half-rises from his stool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What--Waitaminute--What...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meurice is pouring the milk down the sink. He looks innoc up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO MARTY
dialogues.text: Angry but not knowing what to say. He glances around the  bar, sinks slowly back onto his stool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deuce in the corner needs help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty sits staring across the bar for a moment, nods a co of times at nothing in particular, then looks back at the woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...So what're you doing tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going out with Meurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty tosses a beer nut into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him you have a headache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debra gives him a level stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't seem to be communicating--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to hustle me. I don't want  to be hustled. It's as simple as  that. Now that I've communicated,  why don't you leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I own the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, I'm getting bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not surprised, the company you've  been keeping the last ten years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both fall silent as Meurice enters frame. He takes a bottle from the bar and pours himself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing at Meurice's  drink) This.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Daniels. Don't worry, I'm paying  for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point is we don't serve niggers  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where? (he looks over his  shoulder; up and  down the bar) ...I'm very careful about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty tosses back Meurice's drink, then turns to Debra,  smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks I'm kidding. Everybody  thinks I'm kidding; (as he turns to leave) if Ray comes in I'm not home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debra watches him go, then turns back to Meurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. What'd you say your last  name was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are following a large German shepherd as it pads down hall toward a warmly lit room at its end. We hear only th sound of the dog's paws on the hardwood floor, and the fa clicking of billiard balls.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIARD ROOM
dialogues.text: It is a paneled, carpeted room with black leather furnitu and a nine-foot billiard table. Various stuffed animal  trophies are scattered around the room, including a moose head mounted on one wall. Ray stands alone in the foregro shooting pool, an unlit cigarette in his mouth. The room very quiet. In the background the German shepherd enters from the hal sits down in a corner, and benignly watches Ray.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS BEDROOM
dialogues.text: It is expensively appointed; a brightly lit woman's bedro Abby is opening a hinged drawer in a white antique bureau She pulls out a leather handbag, gropes nervously through its contents, then puts it aside. She crosses the room to a vanity table, takes a purse fro underneath, and spills its contents out on top of the tab

dialogues.speaker: BILLIARD ROOM
dialogues.text: Ray pockets a couple of balls, looks over at the dog, the up at the wall at the far end of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanging on the wall are a couple of framed photographs of Marty and Abby, taken a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: Staring at the pictures. He looks back down at the pool t

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Abby is sitting on a large double bed. She puts aside ano purse, rises and crosses the room hurriedly, and pushes b the sliding doors of a long wardrobe closet. The upper sh is lined with handbags--fifteen or twenty of them. She gr the first one, looks in, tosses it aside; grabs the secon looks--and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the purse, a small pearl-handled gun.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIARD ROOM
dialogues.text: Ray is now standing in front of the pictures on the wall, looking from one to the next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A picture of Abby and Marty standing together on a Gulf b Marty is wearing a long velour beach robe, Abby is in a  swimming suit. Ray's hand enters frame. He traces a finge down her leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His head cocked to the side. After a moment his eyes shif

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of Marty's face. He is staring into the camera, at whoeve took the picture. His head is thrown back slightly; he is laughing. From offscreen in the quiet room we hear a static hum and then Abby's voice over an intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray...?

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: He turns from the photograph and walks to an intercom spe next to the mounted moose's head. He presses the speaker  button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He idly takes his unlit cigarette and sticks it in the mo mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You get what you wanted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY'S FRONT FOYER
dialogues.text: We are looking across a dark, high-ceilinged foyer toward the front door. Ray leans against the doorjamb, in silhou in the open doorway. He is facing a curved staircase that descends into the foyer. Abby appears at the second-floor landing and starts down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why d'you wanna leave all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kidding? I don't wanna leave all  this, I just wanna leave Marty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she reaches the bottom of the stairs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Drive me to a motel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can stay at my place, I'll drop  you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where... where you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See a guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) Don't go to the bar, Ray. I know  him, that ain't a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just gotta see a guy.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY'S BAR
dialogues.text: The crowd has thinned out. Meurice and Debra are in the  foreground. Ray enters from the street and makes his way over to them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meurice. Sorry I didn't show last  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't too busy. You missed a good  one, though. This white guy walks in  about one o'clock, asks if we have a  discount for alcoholics... I tell  him to get lost, but Marty's sitting  here listening and I can tell he's  thinking that maybe it ain't such a  bad idea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pours Debra another drink and starts to set one up for Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Ray, this is Debra. She's a  geologist. That's the theory of rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray nods at Debra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Marty here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not here tonight. Wasn't here last  night. He's especially not back in  his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaving) Thanks Meurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty is sitting on the stoop that descends from his back office to a graveled back parking lot; he is framed in th open doorway of his brightly lit office. He stares fixedl at something offscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the middle distance a huge incinerator operates full b Orange flames lick out the sides; white smoke billows out the top. Two figures in silhouette are chucking garbage i through a large gate.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO MARTY
dialogues.text: Behind him, in the office, we see the door from the bar o and Ray entering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty looks over his shoulder, then back toward the furna Ray descends the stoop and stands in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well...? What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty stares past Ray across the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What "what"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I fired? You wanna hit me? What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't particularly want to talk to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... if you're not gonna fire me  I might as well quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Suit yourself. (still staring fixedly  at the furnace) ...Having a good time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray tenses. There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't like this kind of talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty still stares at the furnace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what'd you come here for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no more conciliation) You owe me for two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. She's an expensive piece of  ass...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finally looks up at Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You get a refund though, if you  tell me who else she's been sluicing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want that money. If you wanna tell  me something, fine--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you, a fucking marriage  counselor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray breaks into a strained half-smile. Marty grins humorlessly back, mimicking Ray's smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you smiling at--I'm a funny  guy, right, I'm an asshole? No, no,  that's not what's funny. What's funny  is her. What's funny is that I had  you two followed because, if it isn't  you, she's been sleeping with someone  else...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs a knee in each hand and leans forward, still loo at Ray. He is becoming only slightly more animated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What's really going to be funny  is when she gives you that innocent  look and says, What're you talking  about, Ray, I haven't done anything  funny...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans back again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But the funniest thing to me right  now is that you think she came back  here for you--*that's* what's funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray moves forward and Marty's eyes follow him as he  approaches. Marty's smile abruptly turns to a look of  apprehension. Ray enters frame and brushes past Marty as walks up the stoop, and crosses the back office toward th bar. Marty relaxes, and his gaze returns to the furnace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Come on this property again and  I'll be forced to shoot you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray opens the door to the bar and shuts it softly behind  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Fair notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the cut the music and all other bar noise drops out. W hear only the rhythmic whir of the fan. We tilt down from the ceiling fan to frame Marty, tilted back in his desk c staring up at the fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meurice is standing in the door to the bar. Far behind hi we can see Debra waiting in the dimly lit, deserted bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I thought you were dead. Going  home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I think I'll stay right here in  hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to leave) Kind of a bleak point of view there,  isn't it Marty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meurice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meurice pauses in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't want that asshole near my  money. I don't even want him in the  bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We get a lot of assholes in here,  Marty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meurice and Debra can be heard leaving the bar. Marty loo down at the telephone in front of him on the desk, then p up the receiver and dials. He tilts back in the chair and stares back up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ceiling fan, turning slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the foreground Ray sits behind the wheel of his parked car, slumped back against the seat. He is staring at his story bungalow, in which a couple of lights are burning.  Inside we can faintly hear his telephone ringing. It rings for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby's hand enters frame, hesitates, then after another r picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The is no answer. From the other end we hear only the rhy whir of a ceiling fan.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Marty listens. He says nothing, still tilted back in his  chair, staring at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: RAY'S LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Abby listens. She shifts the phone to her other ear, list hard to the sound of the fan. There is another long pause

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Marty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone goes dead just as we hear the front door openin Abby looks up as she cradles the phone. Ray is standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the phone. Was it for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, he didn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. So how do you know it was a  he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) You got a girl--am I screwing  something up by being here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray leans against the door and folds his arms, watching A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby looks at him, puzzled. After an uncomfortable pause:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I can find a place tomorrow, then  I'll be outta your hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's what you want to do, then  you oughta do it. You, uh... you  want the bed or the couch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby shifts uneasily, looking at Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... the couch would be all  right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can sleep on the bed if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I'm not gonna put you out of  your bed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't be putting me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well, I'd be okay in here--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray walks toward the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY'S OFFICE LATER
dialogues.text: Still tilted back in his chair, Marty stares glumly at th ceiling. The bar itself is completely still except the  rhythmic whir of the fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning slowly. We tilt down from the fan to frame Abby,  lying under a sheet on Ray's couch, staring up at the fan the darkened living room. The room is still. We hear only the whir of the fan and the distant sound of crickets. Ab turns her head, looking offscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ray of light slants up the hallway from the direction o the bedroom. The light is snapped off, leaving the hallwa in darkness. We hear a faint cough and the creaking of  bedsprings.

dialogues.speaker: RAY'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Ray lies in bed, staring at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby sits up. She stands and walks across the moonlit roo toward the hallway. We pull her back down the hall toward the bedroom. She pauses in the bedroom doorway and looks  down toward the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray in bed, his eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO ABBY
dialogues.text: We pull her as she enters the room, then tilt down with h as she hesitantly sits on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close shot, Ray asleep.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO ABBY
dialogues.text: Framed against a moonlit window from the shoulders up. There is a long pause. Ray's hand enters frame and pulls Abby down out of frame  onto the bed. We hold on the moonlit window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window the slow dissolve gradually defines th front lawn and the street beyond in the flat pre-dawn lig Abby rises into frame and quietly gets out of bed. The ca tracks behind her as she walks up the hallway into the li room. We follow her across the living room and move into a clos shot on her hand as she reaches into her purse and withdr a small plastic compact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She flips open the compact, then, hearing something, look up, squinting across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the shadows at the far end of the room we can just see two pointed ears and a glittering pair of eyes. The Germa shepherd is panting softly.

dialogues.speaker: OVER ABBY'S SHOULDER
dialogues.text: As she peers into the shadows, her face reflected in the  mirror of the open compact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opal--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the mirror something moves just behind her. Abby start to turn. Marty's hand clamps over her mouth from behind. His other hand circles her waist. Abby struggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Lover-boy oughta lock his door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty's hand drops from her waist to her thighs and slide under the robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Lotta nuts out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still holding her from behind, Marty forces her down on h knees. Abby's cries are muffled by the hand clamped over mouth. Marty shoots a glance down the dark hallway. There no movement. Abby's hand is groping forward out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She upsets it. The contents spill out, among them a small pearl-handled revolver. Her hand gropes for the gun.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO ABBY AND MARTY
dialogues.text: Marty yanks her to her feet, looking down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's do it outside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is dragging her to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...in nature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes her through the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neighborhood is deserted and still. The streetlamps a still on. Marty and Abby stumble down the front stoop ont the lawn. His hand is still clamped over her mouth. She reaches up, grabs a finger, and bends it back. We hear the bone snap. Marty screams. His hand drops. His other hand cuffs her o the side of the head, spinning her around. Marty is now clutching his broken finger with his good ha Abby kicks him in the groin. He sinks to his knees, drops forward on one hand, and vom

dialogues.speaker: FRONT STOOP
dialogues.text: Ray is coming out the door, hitching up his pants. In his right hand he hold Abby's pearl-handled revolver.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Slowly gets to his feet, looking at Ray.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: She has backed away from Marty and now stands on the lawn breathing heavily. She looks from Ray to Marty.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO MARTY
dialogues.text: Backing toward his car, a Cadillac parked at curbside, st looking at Ray. He turns to get into the car. The German shepherd lopes across the lawn and takes a cle leap into the car through the open window on the passenge side. Marty turns the ignition. The engine coughs and dies. He  tries again; it starts. The car roars up the street.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Watching the car. He looks at Abby.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Still panting. Up the street we can hear Marty's car  alternately racing and stopping, shifting in and out of g His engine rumble starts to grow louder again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like to have seen his face when he  found the dead end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the background we see Marty's car roar by in the oppos direction.

dialogues.speaker: LATERAL TRACK
dialogues.text: Moving past a row of cars parked on an overlook near the of the mountain. Below we can see the lights of the city Austin. The lot is littered with beer cans. We hear the s of rock music coming from various car radios. Several  teenagers lean against cars drinking beer; inside the car we can see the vague forms of others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey mister, how'd you break your  pussyfinger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His friends laugh.

dialogues.speaker: TRACK PULLING MARTY
dialogues.text: Ignoring the laughter as he walks past the cars, apparent looking for someone. His right index finger is taped up i an aluminum splint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of a row of cars we see a green Volkswagon bug Leaning against the hood is Visser, still dressed in his  rumpled yellow suit. He is smoking a cigarette, talking t sixteen-year-old girl in shorts and a tube top. When he  notices Marty:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the girl) Sorry sweetheart, my date is here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl drifts off. Marty enters frame and Visser turns him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...She saw me rolling a cigarette  and thought it was marijuana. (he laughs) I guess she thought I was a swinger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visser open the back door of the car. Marty ignores the  invitation, walks around to the front on the passenger si and gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Visser gets into the driver's seat. A small topless do is suspended from the rearview mirror. Visser gives it a  tap. As it swings back and forth two small lights, one be each breast, blink on and off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Idnat wild?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both men sit watching the doll intently. Finally Marty reaches up and stops its swinging with the  rounded end of his splint. Visser eyes the splint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genially) Stick your finger up the wrong  person's ass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty is silent, but Visser is in a good mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know a friend of mine broke his  hand a while back. Put in a cast.  Very next day he takes a fall,  protects his bad hand, falls on his  good one, breaks that too. So now  he's got two busted flippers and I  say to him "Creighton, I hope your  wife loves you. 'Cause for the next  five weeks you cannot wipe your own  goddamn ass..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overcome by laughter. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...That's the test, ain't it? Test  of true love--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a job for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (settling down) ...Well, if the pay's right and it's  legal I'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not strictly legal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visser shrugs, lights up another cigarette with his  fraternally inscribed lighter and drops the lighter onto dashboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the pay's right I'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's, uh... it's in reference to  that gentleman and my wife. The more  I think about it the more irritated  I get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well how irritated are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty doesn't answer. Finally Visser laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Gee, I'm sorry to hear that. Can  you tell me what you want me to do  or is it a secret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm not--this isn't a joke  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visser eyes him, still smiling. Finally he shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to kill 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that. (a pause) Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty's shoulders slump. He seems less tense, almost reli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, uh... this wouldn't interest  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that. All I said was  you're an idiot. Hell, you been  thinking about it so much it's driving  you simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are staring at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten thousand dollars I'll give you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visser laughs again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to do a murder--two  murders--and just trust you not to  go simple on me and do something  stupid. I mean real stupid. Now why  should I trust you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobering) The money. Yeah. That's a right smart  of money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and gazes out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...In Russia they make only fifty  cents a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He falls silent again, still staring out the window In the closeness of the car Marty is starting to sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hoarsely) ...There's a big--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abruptly) I want you to go fishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go down to Corpus for a few days.  Get yourself noticed. I'll give you  a call when it's done... You just  find a way to cover that money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty is slumped in his seat, not responding to the fact  that Visser has just ended the conversation. Finally he rouses himself and gets out of the car, leavin Visser staring at the door he has left open behind him. After a moment we hear Marty's footsteps approaching agai and he leans back into the open door with an afterthought

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of the money, you  just make sure those bodies aren't  found... There's a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These words are difficult to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...If you want, there's a big  incinerator behind my place...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men look at each other. Marty leaves. After a mom Visser leans over to grab the handle of the still open do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Sweet Jesus, you are disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door slams.

dialogues.speaker: INT. EMPTY APARTMENT NIGHT
dialogues.text: The apartment is dark. We are looking across a shadowy fl towards a large window, through which cold blue street li shines. Through the window we can see the facade of the  building across the street; we are three or four floors u We can hear the animated, accented voice of an Hispanic w approaching the apartment from the hallway behind us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --big windows, paneleen and  everytheen. So you want, like your  own place? Like a Town House?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crack of light shoots across the floor as we hear the  apartment door open behind us. A figure enters frame. As crosses into the shaft of light we see that it is Abby. S moves across the dark apartment, in silhouette against th window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one will bother you here, sweetie--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An overhead light is switched on and the room is bathed i light. Several feet from Abby, an old man in a dirty  undershirt is asleep on a cot. Abby starts. The old man grumbles, slowly sits up, squints. With the light, the window behind Abby has become a mirro of the entire room, in which we now see the matronly Land standing by the wall switch. The Landlady roars at the old man in Spanish. The man glo at her. The Landlady looks back at Abby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerful again) I show you around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Abby as she accompanies the landlady back into short hallway-entrance foyer. Abby glances back at the ol man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure this is... Are you sure  this apartment is vacant?... Mrs.  Esteves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Landlady laughs cheerfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gestures to a kitchen alcove on the left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...That's the kitchen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and throws a few more barbs in Spanish back tow the old man, then opens a door on the right side of the f and enters the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This is the bathroom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She flushes the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The toilet works and everytheen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bustles out of the bathroom and takes the two short s back into the main room. She gestures expansively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And here we are back in the liveen  room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives one vigorous stomp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Good floors. Gas heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...That's Mr. Garcia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man is now sitting on the edge of the bed, smokin cigarette, looking for a place to put the ash. The Landla snaps at him again in Spanish, and is again cheerful as s turns back to address Abby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I was just esplaineen to him that  he moved out of here yesterday...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks to the apartment door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You look around. Don't mind Mr.  Garcia; he use do be my brother-in- law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks out and shuts the door. The room is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staring at the door. She looks at Mr. Garcia, looks nervo around the apartment. She looks back at Mr. Garcia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staring vacantly at Abby. He blows a stream of smoke acro the room. The ash falls off his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: EXHORTER'S CUBICLE
dialogues.text: Hunched over the public address microphone in his small  cubicle of exhortation, is the middle-aged strip-bar bark Years of service in the bar have left his exhortations  depressingly bereft of conviction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout it, gentlemen, let's show  out appreciation for Lorraine up  there, a registered nurse from Bolton,  Texas, how 'bout it gentlemen, yeah...

dialogues.speaker: THE BAR PROPER
dialogues.text: Meurice is one of a line of men sitting at the bar, all  looking intently at the same point off left. All of the m except Meurice are conservatively dressed and apparently  well-to-do. An audio loop is blaring a bump-and-grind ver of "Yellow Rose of Texas," punctuated by the crash of cym and the thumping of toms. Abby enters and sits into an empty chair next to Meurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like the state legislature is  out of session.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meurice continues to stare intently off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought this is where they met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of the heads at the bar start to swivel, including  Meurice's. A couple of patrons hurriedly snatch their dri off the bar. In the extreme foreground a stripper dances on the top of the bar into frame. We crop her just above her white high heeled cowboy boots and her bare calves. The conversation continues with Abby looking at Meurice, Meurice and everyone else at the bar looking up at a poin somewhere above the stripper's calves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen Meurice, you're gonna help me  with a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stripper drops a white leatherette vest onto the bar the foreground. The audience cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna keep an eye on Marty  and Ray, make sure nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two sheriff-star pasties drop onto the bar. The audience  cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Ever occur to you, Abby, that  maybe I'm the wrong person to ask?

dialogues.speaker: THE EXHORTER
dialogues.text: Into his microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not sit on our wallets,  gentlemen. Lorraine is up there  dancing her heart out, and if you  let that cash money set on your hip,  you might just as well be broke...

dialogues.speaker: ABBY AND MEURICE
dialogues.text: She is rising to leave; he is still staring off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Meurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any time. But you don't have to worry  about a thing for a while. Marty  went down to Corpus yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old-west gunbelt hits the bar. The audience roars.

dialogues.speaker: THE EXHORTER
dialogues.text: Into his microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And remember, gentlemen, we're always  here, two to two, A.M. to P.M., three  hundred and sixty-four days and  Christmas, God willing and the creek  don't rise...

dialogues.speaker: RAY'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: The room is dark. We are looking across the room toward a moonlit window. Beyond, across the lawn, the lamplit stre is empty. Suddenly Abby sits bolt upright into frame from the bed b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Offscreen we hear Ray stirring in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby twists around to look down at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could've sworn I heard something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Door's locked. Nothing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls her down out of frame and we hold on the window the empty lamplit street. Then Abby rises back into frame in silhouette against the window, looking down at Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it. 'Cause we wouldn't have  heard anything if it was him. He's  real careful. Fact is, he's anal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he told me once himself. He  said to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She taps herself on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..."In here, Abby. In here... I'm  anal."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking up at Abby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yawning) ...Well I'll be damned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't believe it either...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Framed against the window, looking down at Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Me on the other hand, I got lots  of personality...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drops down onto the bed out of frame. The camera hold on the window through which we see the empty lamplit stre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty always said I had too much.  'Course he was never big on  personality...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rises back up into frame, in silhouette against the  window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He sent me to a psychiatrist to  see if he could calm me down some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psychiatrist said I was the healthiest  person he'd ever met, so Marty fired  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sleepily) ...I don't know if you can fire a  psychiatrist, exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't see him anymore, I'll  tell you that much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes half-closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, Marty, how come you're anal  and I gotta go to the psychiatrist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Framed against the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. He's like you, he doesn't  say much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmuring) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except when he doesn't say things  they're usually nasty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you don't they're usually nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You ever get tired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh, yeah, I guess. Mm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray's hand rises into frame and coaxes Abby back down ont the bed, revealing, through the window, a green Volkswago now parked at curbside on the lamplit street. We hear the rustle of sheets. As we hold on the window, we begin to hear the faint, dis sound of metal scraping against metal.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY / LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: We track down the dark hallway into the living room. As t camera advances the sound of the scraping becomes louder. We are moving across the living room up to the front door the bungalow. The scraping is louder still as we finally  frame on a close shot of the doorknob, which is jiggling  ever so slightly. We hear a click as the lock finally releases. The door swings slowly open, revealing a man's hand on th outside doorknob. We follow the hand as the man advances  slowly and quietly across the living room. Abby's purse comes into frame, sitting on a bureau; next it is a large tote bag. The hand rummages through the tot bag briefly, then the purse. The man withdraws Abby's pea handled revolver. He breaks it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Visser. As we hear a click offscreen, his face glow dim orange.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HIS HANDS
dialogues.text: His right holds the revolver, cylinder open, inside the p His left holds his cigarette lighter as he inspects the  chamber. Three of the holes glint silver, the other three are black--empty. We hear the faint creaking of bedsprings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visser cocks his head, listening, and looks down the hall He takes a couple of quiet steps across the living room a as the camera tracks up to him, opens the back door of th bungalow. We follow him outside onto the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We track behind him as he rounds the corner of the house approaches the open window to Ray's bedroom. He slows, mo more cautiously, then sinks to his knees under the window As he reaches into his breast pocket the camera continues tracking up to and over him, finally framing his POV thro the window. On the bed inside we can dimly see Abby and Ray, asleep. We have been hearing a faint rumble, becoming louder and  louder as if approaching from a distance. Just as the rum becomes deafening a sudden bright flash of light illumina the room, seeming to polarize the image of Abby and Ray i bed, and we:

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PHONE BOOTH DAY
dialogues.text: A huge truck roars by on the street behind Visser, and wi it the deafening rumble recedes. It is a painfully bright day. Visser stands sweating in the phone booth with the  receiver pressed to his ear. We hear the phone ringing at the other end. Finally, it is picked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Is it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya catch any fish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya catch any fish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What kind of fish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, what is it? Is it done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visser forces a chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yessir, you owe me some money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being plopped down onto Marty's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visser sits facing the desk. He lights himself a cigarett and sets the lighter down on the desk in front of him. Ma settles, fidgeting, into the chair behind it. The bar is quiet, shut down. We hear only the whir of a f somewhere offscreen. Marty and Visser are lit by a lamp o the desk between them. Light streams into the room from a bathroom in the background. Visser is looking at the dead fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dully) They look good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty half-rises from his seat and picks up one of the  strings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want a couple?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops them on Visser's side of the desk. Visser's head draws back: he was only being polite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the ten thousand'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got something to show me first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visser hands a 9 x 12 envelope across the desk. Marty sta at it for a moment, then quickly bends back the flap and  takes out an 8 x 10 photograph.

dialogues.speaker: THE PHOTOGRAPH
dialogues.text: It is a black-and-white shot of Abby and Ray in Ray's bed The sheet that partially covers them is pocked with three dark bullet holes and is stained with blood.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Staring dully down at the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it would seem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visser is pushing the fish away from his side of the desk with the eraser end of a pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO MARTY
dialogues.text: Still looking at the picture. He traces the outline of Ab body with his finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What did you do with the bodies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's taken care of. The less you  know about it the better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, I don't believe it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty slips the picture back into its 9 x 12 envelope. Hi face is pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I think I'm gonna be sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises and heads for the bathroom, still clutching the  envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As his eyes follow Marty's exit. The bathroom door doesn' close all the way; a narrow shaft of light slices the off from the bare bulb in the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll want that picture back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to look across the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The standing safe behind the desk.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO VISSER
dialogues.text: Still looking at the safe. Beads of sweat have popped out his forehead. He fans himself with his cowboy hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and you did say somethin' about  some money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a toilet flush offscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he reenters the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your money, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visser stares dully down at the desktop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something I got to ask you, Marty.  I've been very very careful. Have  you been very very careful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody knows you hired me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty is hunched over the open safe, still holding the  envelope. Blocking Visser's view of the safe with his bod he slides the picture of Abby's and Ray's corpses from un the envelope into the safe, then withdraws two packets of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be absurd, I wasn't about to  tell anyone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shuts the safe and spins the dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This is an illicit romance--we've  got to trust each other to be  discreet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks across the room and throws the money and the env down on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...For richer, for poorer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visser looks from the money down at his hands. They are  sweating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say that. Your marriages don't  work out so hot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wipes his hands on his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...How did you cover the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty sits and props his booted feet up on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's taken care of. The less you  know about it the better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I just made a call about that.  It'll look fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) I must've gone money simple. This  kind of murder...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods toward the envelope on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it's too damn risky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you shouldn't have done it.  Can't have it both ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes the money across the desk with his boot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Count it if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching into his  coat) Nah, I trust ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hand comes out with a gun pointing at Marty and--BAM- fires, an orange lick of flame spurting from the gun. Both men sit frozen. Visser's hand is the only thing that moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staring at Visser. After the gun blast we hear only the whir of the fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staring at Marty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are now shut. Otherwise he hasn't moved. A blood stain is growing on the front of his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two face each other across the desk. Visser's gun is  still trained on Marty. After a moment Visser starts fanning himself again with h cowboy hat. The only movement in the frame is the slow ba and-forth of the yellow hat, rhythmically in and out of s as it catches and loses the light from the desk lamp. The is a long pause. Finally one of Marty's feet slips from the desk and hits floor with a THUD. Visser lays the gun on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he reaches into his breast pocket and withdraws a  handkerchief. He wipes his forehead, then picks up the gu and wipes it off. He leans down with the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Visser places it deliberately on the floor near the de It is Abby's pearl-handled revolver.

dialogues.speaker: THE DESKTOP FROM DESK LEVEL
dialogues.text: As Visser straightens up in the foreground. From our head angle shooting across the desk we can see the bright meta glint of Visser's cigarette lighter underneath the dead f Visser's hands move over the near part of the desk, picki up the money and the 9 x 12 picture envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Visser turns from the desk and walks across the room o of frame. We hear the back door opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who looks stupid now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door slams shut. The only sound is the whir of the fan. A pause. The camer tracks slowly forward, tilting down to keep Marty and the desktop centered in frame. As the camera moves the noise the fan grows louder. When Marty's body and the desk are  directly beneath us, the blades of the ceiling fan cut ac the immediate foreground and effect a:

dialogues.speaker: MARTY'S BAR LATER
dialogues.text: It is completely still. We are looking from the bar, acro the dark empty floor, toward the pebbled windows at the f of the building that catch a hard blue light from the  streetlamps outside. The jukebox in the middle distance g in the darkness. A pair of headlights catches the pebbled glass and grows  brighter as we hear a car pull up to the bar and stop. We hear a car door open and shut, then the sound of feet on  gravel. A huge shadow appears on the pebbled glass as the figure crosses in front of the headlights. The man tries door, finds it locked, and walks back in front of the  headlights to cup his hands at a window. He walks back to the door, and a moment later it swings open--framing him the doorway in silhouette. We follow him as he moves across the floor, behind the ba and up to the cash register. He switches on a small  fluorescent light clamped to the top of the cash register It is Ray. He punches a key and the register rings open. He lifts up the empty cash drawer and takes some papers from undernea it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he flips through the papers; bills, receipts, no money

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: As he finishes flipping through the papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) Damn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slips them back under the cash drawer and slams the  register shut. Turning from the register he glances aroun the bar, the pauses, noticing something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light is spilling out from under the door to Marty's offi

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: As he starts across the floor to Marty's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches the door and knocks sharply. No answer. He tur the knob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is locked. We hear the muffled whir of the ceili fan inside. A pause. Ray withdraws a ring of keys from his pocket and uses one on the door. The door swings open. Over his shoulder we see Marty, still at his desk, his ba to us. On foot is still propped on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, you deaf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. Ray stumbles toward Marty. He stumbles slightly and we hear the sharp blast of a gun and the sound of something metallic skating across the fl Ray, startled, steadies himself against the desk, then st Marty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a dark pool of blood under Marty's chair.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: He looks back up at Marty, then walks behind his chair an throws a wall switch. The room is bathed in light. His ey still on Marty, Ray crosses behind the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera moves in a slow arc around the back of Marty's motionless head.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: Still moving. He looks away from Marty, scans the floor. gets down on his hands and knees and peers under the safe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a glinting silver circle in the darkness under t safe. It is the business end of the revolver that Ray hal stumbled over, half-kicked.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: Still on his hands and knees. He reaches in and we hear a rattle as he gropes under the safe. He withdraws the gun, looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: THE GUN
dialogues.text: It is Abby's revolver.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: For a long moment he doesn't move. Then, slowly, he start to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The desk, Marty behind it, Ray straightening behind him. looks from the gun to Marty, slowly sets the gun down on desk. A pause. He begins to hoist Marty from the chair. There is noise from the bar, as of someone entering. Ray reacts.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR
dialogues.text: Separating the bar and back office. Ray hurries to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Footsteps approach the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns it gently. The bolt clicks shut.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: Meurice's footsteps draw nearer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty, ya home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a rap at the door; Ray stands frozen. The doorkn rattles. Ray reaches out compulsively to grab it, but sto himself before actually touching it. Now Meurice's footsteps can be heard going casually back  into the bar. We hold on Ray's rigidly set face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What day is it today, Angie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuesday is ladies' night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuesday night is ladies' night. All  your drinks are free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a record drop on the jukebox and a Motown song bl Ray crosses to Marty's chair and takes off his nylon  windbreaker. He stoops down and tries to mop up the pool blood with his windbreaker. This isn't going to work. He rises and walks over to the bathroom, the windbreaker  dripping blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The song continues faintly in the background. The faucet turned on and Ray's hand enters frame, holding a dirty wh towel under the stream of water.

dialogues.speaker: BLOOD-SPATTERED FLOOR
dialogues.text: The song continues in the background. Ray's hand enters f holding the balled-up towel. His windbreaker is wrapped  inside. The camera follows as he pushes it across the tra of dripped blood to the pool of blood under Marty's chair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He still has not moved. Ray rises into frame and takes hi under the armpits. He notices something on the desk in fr of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray's hand enters frame and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray's hand enters frame and slips the gun into Marty's po Marty is hoisted up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray appears in the doorway. The music from the bar, thoug fainter, can still be heard. There are three or four wooden steps going down from the  back door to the small gravel parking lot in back. Ray ba down the stairs; Marty's feet THUMP-THUMP-THUMP down the  stairs after him. The rear door of Ray's car is open. Ray heaves in Marty's torso. Marty's legs rest on the ground outside the car. R takes an ankle in each hand and pushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he shuts the door. He looks up across the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The incinerator belching fire and smoke. We hear its dist roar over the bar song. We hear the car door slam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are looking down on Ray's car as the camera tracks beh it towards the incinerator. At the cut the roar of the  incinerator is suddenly louder. It grows louder still as approach it. Ray's car draws even with the incinerator without slowing stopping. The wadded-up towel is chucked out of his windo into the fire. We hold on the fire as Ray's car rolls on of frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he drives down a deserted country highway. We hear the rhythmic sound of the wheels clomping over asphalt. The r is broadcasting a fundamentalist's sermon, periodically  interrupted by static. Ray is sweating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --so there were three signs, the  second of which is Famine, this famine  which I have already pointed out is  devastatin' Africa and the Indian  subcontinent. And the third of these  signs is earthquakes. Now I don't  know why he threw that in but if you  talk to a geologist, and I've talked  to many, he'll tell you that  earthquake activity--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray twists around and looks in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty is lying inert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --has increased almost eighty percent  in the past two years, and what's  more, in two years' time we'll be  experiencin' what's knows as the  Jupiter Effect--

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: He looks back at the road. A car roars by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --wherein all the planets of the  known universe will be aligned up  causin' an incredible buildup of  destructive gravitational force. Now  in Matthew Chapter Six, Verse Eighteen  the Lord out and tells us that these  are the signs by which we shall know  that He is at our door. There are  many good people disagree with me,  but it's my belief that this  Antichrist is alive today and livin'  somewhere in Europe, in that ten- nation alliance I spoke of, bein'  groomed for his task--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray switches off the radio. We hear the sound of faint, labored breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His jaw tightens. He whips his head toward the back seat. His head snaps forward again and he slams on the brakes. The car screeches to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ray's door flies open. He is bolting from the car. The camera, at waist level, tracks toward him as he races out into the field that abuts the highway. Fifty yards in he finally stops, panting, framed from a l angle. His breath vaporizes in the crisp night air. We he only his breath and the chirring of crickets. He is looki back toward the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing abandoned on the shoulder of the deserted highwa Its headlights cast a lonely beam up the road. No movemen

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: His panting slows. He is in a cold sweat. After a long mo he starts walking slowly, reluctantly, back toward the ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toward the car. Still no sign of movement.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: He slows as he draws up to the back of the car. He looks the back window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is empty. The door on the highway side is ajar.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: No reaction. He walks around the back of the car onto the highway. He  looks up the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty is crawling up the road on his hands and knees, lea a trail of blood. The headlights of Ray's car give a  fantastically long shadow.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: Still no reaction. He gets into the driver's seat and sta through the windshield as he gropes for the ignition key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty, crawling.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: He throws the car into drive, looks at his target, thinks decides. He pulls the key out of the ignition and goes ar to the trunk of the car. He opens it and pulls out a shov

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From in front. The headlights glare behind him. His breat vaporizes. In the background Ray is walking toward him,  dragging the shovel, which scrapes along the asphalt. As moves into the foreground and turns to face Marty only hi lower legs and the shovel are in frame. The shovel rises out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both hands hold the shovel tensed over his shoulder. He s down at Marty. A long pause. We hear a distant rumble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inches away from Marty. Marty's hand slides forward and w around one of Ray's ankles.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: He shudders. He adjusts his grip on the shovel. The rumble grows louder.

dialogues.speaker: RAY'S FEET
dialogues.text: He jerks his foot away, breaking Marty's grasp.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: Looks up from Marty. The rumble grows louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headlight beams, although not yet the headlights themselv are visible a long way down the road.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RAY
dialogues.text: Staring down the road. Finally he lowers the shovel, walk back to the car and throws it viciously into the trunk, w back up into the foreground and stoops down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ray grabs him under the armpits and starts dragging hi back to the car. Just before Ray heaves him into the back seat, Marty coughs weakly. A fine spray of blood comes ou with the cough. The engine rumble is quite loud now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he slams the back door shut. He presses himself agains the side of the car. Headlights glare over him; the truck roars by just behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sudden quiet at the cut. We are looking at Ray's car in  profile, parked in the middle of a deserted field.
